body.p: This small tutorial is based on the "DITA Linking Strategies" presentations I made for the DITA Europe 2016 and DITA North America 2017 conferences. It's a general overview about DITA linking possibilities and best practices. And it's meant as a continuation of the DITA Reuse Strategies blog post.
According to Wikipedia: "A link, is a reference to data that the reader can directly follow either by clicking, tapping, or hovering."

Basically we should regard linking as yet another form of content reuse, only that instead of presenting the content in place, it re-directs the end user to some other resource. And we'll start with describing linking at DITA Map level.

section.title: Map-Level Linking
section.p: A DITA Map uses topic references to assemble the content of the publication. <topicref href="installation.dita"> <topicref href="server_installation.dita"/> <topicref href="client_side_installation.dita"/> </topicref>

Depending on the output format, the topic reference may be a link in the table of contents for the XHTML based outputs or it may be interpreted as a content reference for the PDF based output which generates a single monolith document. So the role of the topicref is dual, it may sometimes be regarded as a link to a topic and sometimes as a content reference.

section.title: Chunking
section.p: DITA topic modules should be kept as small as possible but sometimes the end user may need to read more than one topic in order to achieve a single task. So when publishing to HTML-based outputs you will end up asking yourself this question:Should I prefer larger HTML files or more links in the TOC?

And you should always consider these two ideas:
Links are disruptive. Ideally users would not need to jump around in content to read the entire story they are searching for.
Small topics which are usually consecutively read by the end user can probably get merged together.

For example if the installation of your product requires installing both a server side and a client side components, using DITA chunking you can choose to have separate DITA topic modules for each of the installation procedures but to merge the topics together in the web-based outputs:<map> <title>User Guide</title> <topicref href="installation.dita" chunk="to-content"> <topicref href="server_installation.dita" toc="no"/> <topicref href="client_side_installation.dita" toc="no"/> </topicref> </map>

You can read more about chunking in the DITA 1.3 specification. The DITA Style Guide also has a good overview about why you should prefer writing small topics and them merging them together using the chunking mechanism.

section.title: Topic-level linking
section.p: Links which appear inside topics can be roughly divided in various categories and we'll try to discuss each of these categories separately.

section.title: In-Content Links
section.p:
In-content links are links added manually in the topic content:
  • See:

You should keep in mind that this kind of links are disruptive to the reading experience because when end users encounter them they need to decide weather to read further on or to follow the link. But this may be a good thing sometimes. For example one of the installation steps may require the end user to download a certain library from an external website before continuing.
You can read more about links in general in the DITA 1.3 specification. The DITA Style Guide written by Tony Self also discourages the use of in-content links.

section.title: Related Links
section.p: Related links are placed at the end of the DITA topic and they allow the end user to explore additional resources after the current topic has been read.<related-links> <link href="http://tomcat.apache.org/" format="html" scope="external"/> </related-links>
In order to minimize disruption when reading the content in general the preferred place where to place links is at the end of the generated HTML page.
You can read more about related links in the DITA 1.3 specification.

section.title: Defining related links using Relationship Tables
section.p: Related links do not need to be manually added at the end of each topic. You can define relationship tables in the DITA Map:<reltable> <relrow> <relcell> <topicref href="client_side_installation.dita"/> </relcell> <relcell> <topicref href="server_installation.dita"/> </relcell> </relrow> …….. </reltable>
These tables can define associations between two or more topics, associations which automatically contribute to the related links creation in the generated HTML output.

Here are a couple of benefits of relationship tables:
A topic should have as few links as possible defined directly in it. This makes it easier to reuse the topic in various contexts and keeps it as separate as possible for other parts of the DITA project, decreasing the possibility of broken links.
By default links defined in relationship tables are bi-directional allowing users to land on any of the topics when searching for solutions and find their way to the related ones.
Relationship table separates the task of writing topics from the task of finding relations between topics.
You can read more about relationship tables in the DITA 1.3 specification. The DITA Style Guide recommends using relationship tables.

section.title: Indirect Links (Key References)
section.p:
All the link samples we've look at so far have been direct links, links which point to the target using the href attribute. Indirect links require two steps:
Define a key in the DITA Map for the target.<keydef keys="client_installation" href="client_side_installation.dita"/>
Use the defined key to refer to the target resources.<xref keyref="client_installation"/>

Here are some of the benefits of indirect linking:
Reuse link target text and meta data. If you want to have custom text for a certain link, you can define it directly in the DITA Map:<keydef keys="dita_ot_website" href="http://www.dita-ot.org/" format="html" scope="external"> <topicmeta> <linktext>DITA Open Toolkit Web Site</linktext> </topicmeta> </keydef>and then add key references in all other places:<xref keyref="dita_ot_website"/>
Easier Conditional linking (including links to topics which sometimes may be missing). If you want your topic to link either to one target or to another depending on the filtering/profiling conditions, instead of adding profiling directly on the link you can add the profiling conditions directly in the DITA Map: <topicref keys="slicing" href="slicing_vegetables_for_experts.dita" audience="expert"/> <topicref keys="slicing" href="slicing_vegetables_for_novices.dita" audience="novice"/> <keydef keys="slicing" audience="noLink"><topicmeta><keywords> <keyword>Slicing</keyword></keywords></topicmeta> </keydef>and then link to the key from each topic: <xref keyref="slicing"/>
Easier Link Management. A good overview about all the outbound links in your project helps you maintain and control lists of allowed external web sites. With indirect references, you can define all references to external resources in a separate DITA Map. An example of a DITA project using indirect links to achieve separation of links by purpose can be found here: .
Easier move/rename topics. When you move or rename a topic referenced via indirect links, only the link defined in the DITA Map will break, making it easier to fix broken links.
There is an overview about indirect addressing on the DITA XML Org website. The DITA 1.3 specification also has a chapter about indirect links.

section.title: Auto-generated Links
section.p:
Until now we've talked about manually added links, either in the topic or in relationship tables. Using the DITA collection-type attribute you can define in the DITA Map relationships between parent and child topic references, relationships which result in automatic links added between them: <topicref href="installation.dita" collection-type="sequence"> <topicref href="server_installation.dita"/> <topicref href="client_side_installation.dita"/> </topicref> There are about 3 useful types of collection-type values:
Unordered - Links are generated from parent to children, and from children to parent.
Family - Links are generated from parent to children, from children to parent, and from sibling to sibling.
Sequence - Links are generated from parent to children, from children to parent, and from child to previous sibling (if applicable) and next sibling (if applicable).
You can read more about auto-generated links in the DITA Style Guide.

section.title: Conditional Links in Distinct Publications
section.p: You may publish from the same DITA content documentation for multiple products. And you may want to have links point to various targets depending on each product for which you want to publish the documentation. Or you may want to suppress links completely in certain publications.

When using direct linking you will need to profile each link depending on the publication:Find our more about slicing vegetables: <xref href="slicing_vegetables_for_experts.dita" audience="expert"/> <xref href="slicing_vegetables_for_novices.dita" audience="novice"/>.With indirect links you can define the profiling attributes as DITA Map level: <topicref keys="slicing" href="slicing_vegetables_for_experts.dita" audience="expert"/> <topicref keys="slicing" href="slicing_vegetables_for_novices.dita" audience="novice"/>and thus simplify the reference made in the topic content:Find our more about slicing vegetables: <xref keyref="slicing/>.

body.section:
Conditional Links in the same publication
Using DITA 1.3 key scopes you can reuse a topic multiple times in a DITA Map and have each referenced topic contain links to various target topics. For example if my preparing_vegetables.dita topic has a link:<link keyref="slicing"/>you can define in the DITA Map various key scopes which bind the "slicing" key to various targets: <topichead navtitle="Cooking for Experts" keyscope="expert"> <topicref href="preparing_vegetables.dita" keys="preparing"/> <topicref href="slicing_vegetables_for_experts.dita" keys="slicing"/> </topichead> <topichead navtitle="Cooking for Novices" keyscope="novice"> <topicref href="preparing_vegetables.dita" keys="preparing"/> <topicref href="slicing_vegetables_for_novices.dita" keys="slicing"/> </topichead>
This previous blog post should contain more details about key scopes.

section.title: Link Text
section.p: When linking to an external resource or to a DITA topic or element, the publishing engine will attempt to deduce the link text from the target context. For example the link to a DITA topic or element which contains a title will use that title as the link text. The link to an external resource (for example to http://www.oxygenxml.com) will use by default the HTTP location as the link text. You can also customize each link text individually. So if you ask yourself this question:

p.lq: Should I leave the link text to be automatically computed or should I set a more friendly text?

section.p: For internal links to elements having a title in general it is more flexible not to set a custom text and let the publishing engine decide one for you. For external links you should usually specify your custom link text.

section.title: Should I link or should I reuse?
section.p: Let's say you want to bring to the end user's attention a certain paragraph, note or section. If that particular target element is not very large you should always prefer reusing it (using a content reference) instead of linking to it.

section.title: Conclusions
section.p:
The problem with managing links in a growing DITA project is the same problem with all larger projects, you need to get yourselves organized. As an overview of what we've discussed so far I would suggest the following best practices:
Linking is a form of reuse so:
Reuse small pieces of content instead of linking to them
Avoid too much linking (Linking is disruptive)
Prefer using indirect links. It will allow you to reuse link text and make profiling/filtering easier while giving you a better overview on the outbound links for your project.
